video.title: Thief VR: Legacy of Shadow | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
Say, wasn&#39;t my first review of 2025 a 
VR game as well? That&#39;s right, Batman:

Arkham Shadow. There must be something about the 
ticking over of the new year that makes me want

to stick my head around the door of VR and check 
to see if we&#39;re living in the Lawnmower Man future

yet. So over the holidays, I tried out Thief VR: 
Legacy of Shadow. Which also has the word &quot;shadow&quot;

in the title, in a slightly uncanny parallel, but 
it&#39;s appropriate because a shadow is exactly the

thing I need to put over my face after a couple 
of hours in VR, which you&#39;ll recall stands for

Violently Regurgitating. Thief VR was recommended 
to me by a colleague since he knows I&#39;m a fan of

the old Thief games, and I guess he thought this 
would help me finally reach the &quot;acceptance&quot; stage

of the grieving process because my goodness me, 
this game&#39;s a pile of shit. The first warning

sign was that it used the logo of the most recent 
Thief game, which in terms of marketing to fans

of the franchise is like trying to sell people 
on a bûche de Noël by making it look uncannily

like a massive dog turd. And the really pathetic 
thing is that it&#39;s obviously trying to haul the

neo-Thief IP back towards the old, good ones like 
it&#39;s pulling on the reins of a terrified horse.

So characters say &quot;Taff&quot; again, and there 
are secret treasures referencing quest

items from Thief 1, and the Mechanists 
from Thief 2 show up again at one point,

curiously glossing over the fact that Thief 
2 ended with the Mechanists turning into

robot slaves and genociding themselves, and most 
importantly, they bring back Stephen Russell as

the voice of Garrett. He&#39;s not the main character, 
though. He&#39;s a voice in the main character&#39;s head,

speaking just often enough that they could justify 
putting his name on a poster but not so much that

the recording booth session would&#39;ve taken more 
than an afternoon of the man&#39;s time. And all of

this in execution is akin to the massive dog turd 
acquiring a light dusting of powdered sugar. Thief

VR: Legacy of Shoddy follows Magpie, a young thief 
in the capital-C City where there&#39;s an evil noble

who controls the corrupt City Watch, and there&#39;s 
a blend of medieval and electropunk technology,

and sentence gradually trails into slurring, 
bluh. In short, absolutely bugger all has changed

in whatever time has elapsed since previous 
Thief games except there was apparently some

citywide rezoning protocol that means all 
the buildings have to be really titchy now.

The death spiral of the Thief series began with 
Thief 3 when the march of graphics technology

precluded the complex, sprawling, open-ended maps 
of the early games, and that spiral continues

right down the S-bend with this one. We sneak our 
way through a succession of painfully small maps,

all with much the same aesthetic and populated 
by a handful of clones of the same three guards,

voiced by the first three dudes who showed up to 
the audition who could put on a mildly convincing

British accent, at least one of whom was probably 
a confused DoorDasher. They&#39;re quite easy to

stealth around because they have the modern 
stealth game habits of having patrol routes

no longer than their own height and frequently 
vocalize every thought that crosses their mind at

full volume as if under the impression that there 
are casting agents trapped inside the walls. That

said, whether or not you&#39;re hidden in shadow only 
seems to be related to how much light is falling

on you about 50 percent of the time, so I was 
still getting spotted a fair bit. You have the

mandatory Thief visibility gem, but it&#39;s stuck 
in the back of your hand, and the only people

who have the backs of their hands in view at all 
times are typists and enthusiastic Nazis. When

you get spotted, obviously, you have to fight 
whoever spotted you, which brings us to combat.

Now, I&#39;ve previously stated that the combat in a 
stealth-focused game is kind of supposed to suck

because if it comes to that, you&#39;ve already fucked 
up, and that&#39;s a philosophy I fear Legacy of

Showaddywaddy took a little bit too much to heart. 
The idea is you&#39;re supposed to parry incoming

attacks by swinging your blackjack in specific 
ways. Quick question: how the fuck can a wooden

and leather cosh wielded by a schoolgirl with a 
Northern accent and about three acting lessons

stop a sword thrust from a professional soldier? 
Quick answer, listeners: it fucking can&#39;t. At

least not for me. I just could not get the parry 
to consistently work outside the tutorial. On the

bright side, it did mean that I managed to get the 
&quot;No Alerts&quot; and &quot;No Kills&quot; award on every single

mission because before long, if I got spotted at 
all, I&#39;d just roll my eyes and smash Quickload

like a hypochondriac with a Life Alert bracelet. 
Christ, that simile showed my age, didn&#39;t it? Oh,

and combat is basically the only way to lose 
health, so if you never engage with it, you never

need healing items, and that&#39;s another entire 
branch of the gameplay risk/reward tree that can

be entirely disregarded, sawn off, and minced 
up to be added to inexpensive school dinners.

And it&#39;s a flimsy-ass game before it starts 
rendering its own mechanics obsolete one by

one. There&#39;s a list of upgrades you can buy if you 
achieve certain objectives, but the game&#39;s so easy

it fucking literally ran out of upgrades to give 
me about four missions in. But let&#39;s get back to

the story. &#39;Cause the whole plot justification 
for bringing back Stephen Russell is that Magpie

finds an old cybernetic eye containing Garrett&#39;s 
spirit and it forcefully bonds with her—which

I took to mean replaced one of her real eyes 
in a theoretically upsetting but in practice

glossed-over kind of way—at which point she hears 
his voice in her head. But what makes it feel so

cynical is that this has literally no bearing on 
anything else. Garrett doesn&#39;t become a mentor

figure because Magpie already has one, a lady 
named Cassandra who fences her loot for her but

is otherwise a straight plot functionary with all 
the characterization of a whiteboard that doesn&#39;t

even use multiple colors of dry-erase marker. 
Garrett&#39;s status is also bugger all to do with

the game&#39;s central objective, which is to stop 
the evil nobleman from performing a magic ritual

that will... do... something. Something bad. I 
think someone mentioned it destroying the city,

but I forget the specifics. Moot 
point anyway because in the end,

we foil the ritual by walking around a room, 
pressing three buttons to almost no resistance.

So Garrett&#39;s only purposes are (1) justify 
the Witcher Vision mechanic wherein the

things you&#39;re obviously meant to notice acquire 
glowing halos to make them even more obvious,

and (2) act as fucking DVD commentary track, 
making a token snarky response to everything

Magpie says. Not particularly gelling 
with Garrett&#39;s established personality,

and Stephen Russell doesn&#39;t sound into it 
either. There is a struggle going on in the

world of VR. On one side, we have developers 
making games for it that are significant,

full-on instalments of their respective 
franchises, like Half-Life: Alyx, Arkham Shadow,

maybe Deadpool VR—which is okay if you can both 
stomach VR motion sickness AND Neil Patrick Harris

making poo jokes for 10 hours—and on the other 
side, you have quite a lot of games like Thief:

Shadowy Legover, which are short, flimsy 
reminders that a franchise exists at best;

the equivalent of a pop-up book version of a 
classic film aimed to help low-attention-span

toddlers understand the thing mummy and daddy seem 
to like. One type of game enforces VR as a viable,

legitimate platform for the artistry of 
games; the other enforces its status as

a gimmicky toy for a niche audience with strong 
gag reflexes. The battle rages on, and Thief VR

has very firmly planted its flag. Into its own 
foot. Because it&#39;s a useless fucking knobend.
